args: Put this article into one of the following categories. Use the most specific category that makes sense. If you are unsure, respond Other. The allowed categories are: Abortion, AI, Associated Press, Birthright citizenship, CFPB, Climate, Crypto, D.C., Debt ceiling, DEI in schools, DEI in the federal government, Department of Education, Deportations, DOGE, End birthright citizenship, Eric Adams case, Expanding executive power, Federal funding, Federal grant pause, Federal office space, Federal worker buyout, Federal workers return to office, Federal workforce reductions, FEMA, Firing government watchdogs, Food safety, Foreign aid, Foreign policy, Gaza, Government shutdown, Guantánamo Bay, Health agencies' communications pause, Health care, Immigration policy, Interest rates, Iran, Islamic State, Israel, Jan. 6, Kennedy Center, NIH, NYC congestion toll, Other, Panama Canal, Pardons, Reclassifying federal jobs, Sanctions, Senior government officials ousted, Taiwan, Targeting political enemies, Targeting protesters, Tariffs, The media, TikTok ban, Transgender policy, U.S.-Mexico border, USAID, USPS, War in Ukraine, World Health Organization Respond ONLY with the category. Trump plans to further restrict undocumented immigrants from public benefits President Donald Trump plans to sign an executive order Wednesday evening aimed at restricting undocumented immigrants’ access to financial benefits from federally funded programs, though they already are generally ineligible for most federal public benefits. White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt confirmed Trump’s plans to sign the executive order on X, reposting a report from Fox News reporter Bill Melugin that said the order “will direct every federal agency & department to identify all federally funded programs currently providing any financial benefits to illegal aliens, and ‘take corrective action.’” The action, according to Melugin’s reporting, may be designed to target immigrants who are granted humanitarian parole by the U.S. Department of Homeland Security. Along with lawful permanent residents, refugees, people granted asylum and victims of abuse or trafficking, people with parole have access to additional benefits, but are still excluded in many cases, according to the National Immigration Law Center. Some of the benefits available to people regardless of immigration status include emergency disaster assistance, school breakfast and lunch programs and certain public health programs, according to the NILC.
